review_title: Wonderful students, but overworked, underpaid, with uncaring administration
job_title: Limited Term Faculty in Valdosta, GA
pros: My students made my job wonderful and worthwhile. I also had many wonderful and supportive faculty colleagues. The campus is very pretty.
cons: The administration treats faculty like cogs in a machine that can make money for them. They clearly care more about the bottom line than about quality education or faculty scholarship. The "student as customer" model is entrenched in the culture. The old boys network that runs this institution (and the USG in general) isn't even hidden. Faculty salaries are quite low; people with doctorates are very regularly paid $45k or less a year, and yet they have the audacity to solicit faculty for donations to the university. The teaching load is also very high for the type of institution and the salary; non tenure-track faculty generally teach a 5-5 load, and tenure-track faculty teach a 4-4 load. There is zero job security, and administrators will say one thing and do another when it comes to retaining faculty. If you have any other options, do not take a faculty job here.

pros: I have worked at VSU since 2007. In my experience I have found that the University has given me a valuable career from a student technician role all the way up to a full-time director role. I appreciate the value that VSU has given me to continue to grow.
cons: Compensation is improving. However, I started off 25% below fair market value. The old guard perspective is shifting and the market landscape for VSU is changing for the better. Unfortunately, I among many others will need to wait 5 years before being fully bumped to fair market value. This is ok, however, I feel that what makes this a negative for current employees is that newly hired staff/faculty will be automatically bumped to the correct salary. This is something that many including myself aren't happy about. However, I do enjoy the work environment and friendly/collaborative culture at VSU.

pros: Throughout my time in both my undergraduate and graduate programs at VSU, I held several different positions. Valdosta State taught me how to be a strong employee with a customer service centered outlook. This institution is not one without its share of unique challenges, but it is one that hires people who care about what they do. When I think back to my work experiences, I think of strong, talented leadership teams who were invested in making me grow professionally. I will always hold a special place in my heart for the time I spent in Housing and Residence Life, Orientation and Admissions, Centralized Advising, and Career Opportunities.
cons: Like any University System of Georgia school, VSU has had some challenges. For the stretch of time I spent in undergrad, I saw a lot of turnover in the President's office, but by the time I entered graduate school, it seemed that office had finally found a good match. I think VSU, like a lot of other higher education institutions needs to continue to unlearn biases and walk toward inclusion and equality for all their marginalized students more than they have in the past.

pros: I greatly enjoyed my time working at VSU. The working environment was friendly, hardworking, and drama free. Based on my previous jobs, I know that these are hard factors to find in a job. I am now employed elsewhere and I continue to say that working at Valdosta State was the best job I have ever had.
cons: The only con I can think of was that since I was a student I was only permitted to work 20 hours a week, but at the same time I can understand that school comes first and they want to ensure that student employees can stay on track with their education.

review_title: Enjoyed working as a GA for Housing & Residence Life at VSU
pros: The supervisors/directors in the Housing Office are really personable and really make you feel at home. They understand that school comes first and work around your schedule. They've given me plenty of opportunities to prove myself with my marketing capabilities with the creation and implementation of contests and promotional materials.
cons: I disliked having to edit newsletters, brochures, and the student planner. This was boring and I felt I could be doing better things with my time by having a student assistant handle the edits. However, it did allow me to develop a more keen eye for details.

review_title: Overall a beautiful campus with great people
pros: VSU has a great small campus atmosphere with genuine people who want to make the university all that it can be. Many people strive to make VSU a wonderful workplace, and everyone gets along very well.
cons: Some things simply don't change when they should. If a security vulnerability is discovered, someone in security should be at fault. A 'hacker' shouldn't be at blame when it's someone's job to prevent vulnerabilities.

review_title: Not bad as a student and employee, not sure I would recommend otherwise..
job_title: IT Helpdesk Technician in Valdosta, GA
pros: I liked how if you were a staff member, you also had the opportunity to continue with your education.  I also thought that usually the work place wasn't bad in my department, though there is usually a lot of politicking going on.
cons: Policies often seem to change on a twice yearly basis, and often the work will go from way to little, to way to much very quickly depending on the time of year.  Advancement is possible, but in many cases unlikely, unless you are willing to redefine your profession often.

pros: Beautiful campus in a pleasant small city with affordable housing. The university has grown from small college to medium sized university in the last 30 years. Good biology department, among other solid programs. High value education for the students.
cons: Upper level administration has been weak and unstable (five presidents in the six years I have worked here). They call it a university, but the leadership runs it more like a "teaching college"...and the faculty are conflicted about the direction and mission of the university (as many worked here when it was a 2000 student teaching college). Not a bad job if you are willing to abandon research, do your teaching, and focus more on university service and administration...but if you want to be an excellent scholar and teacher it is a really tough place to work (even though they tried to sell me on teaching/research balance). The pay is insulting (unless you are business or computer science or upper admin) and the weakest departments with the least talented faculty often get the highest salaries because they have the most trouble attracting good people). Administration does not see the connection between academic excellence and faculty excellence and student success. They let any student in that has a brain cell and then want you to focus on retention by providing better service to the students. The administration is hyper-focused on marginal changes in admission numbers, rather than looking at overall numbers. They fail to rally around the real strengths of the university and rather tout that they are 109th best in online programs. It's a tragedy because this school could be a regional powerhouse and local economic driver, but the college mentality inhibits them from making strategic investments in faculty and the city that could really grow the university's influence.

pros: The office that I work is fabulous, there are some really great individuals here. Everyone gets alone and I actually enjoy coming to work everyday. Despite some of the issues I have with my office, the environment is great.
cons: My manager, I believe, has not been adequately trained on how to manage. My manager lacks in people skills, and frequently falls apart when stress levels are high.

review_title: Good Job while in school but not after
